note_models.name: Basic-49a6a

fields: Among many other things, what is a web browser mainly?
A HTTP Client
What does a HTTP client communicate with?
A HTTP Server
Define a server
A server is not hardware, it is a process running at an advertised location providing a service
What does HTTP stand for
HyperText Transfer Protocol
What does SMTP stand for
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol
What does DNS stand for
Domain Name System
What does LDAP stand for
Lightweight Directory Access Protocol
What does SMB stand for
Server Message Block
What does IP stand for
Internet Protocol
What does TCP stand for
Transmission Control Protocol
What does UDP stand for
User Datagram Protocol
Clients and servers use an accepted ? to communicate
Protocol
What is a protocol
An accepted method of exchanging messages between the client and the server
What 3 things does a HTTP request consist of

A Method (GET)
A Path (/)
A Protocol Version (HTTP/1.1)

GET / HTTP/1.1
What style if protocol is HTTP
A request/response style protocol
What does URL stand for
Uniform Resource Locator
What 3 elements does a URL consist of

The Scheme (https://)
The Authority (example.com)
The Path (/example)

https://example.com/example
4 examples of the protocols used in URLs include

http
ftp
mailto
file
What 3 elements can the Authority element of a URL consist of

User info (username@)
The host (example.com)
The port (:8080)

username@example.com:8080
What does FQDN stand for
Fully-Qualified Domain Name
What 2 elements does a FQDN consist of

The host name (www)
The domain name (.ecu.edu.au)

www.ecu.edu.au
How many bits is an IPv4 address
32-bit
What 2 elements does an IP address consist of

The network portion (192.168.1.)
The host portion (205)

192.168.1.205
IP addresses are represented in what number format
Dotted decimal
A 32-bit IP is divided in how many bytes

Four 8-bit bytes

24bits (3bytes) for the network portion
8bits (1byte) for the host portion
What is the purpose of a subnet mask

To allow us to isolate the network address by AND'ing then together

255.255.255.0
11111111.11111111.11111111.00000000
What is the purpose of the wildcard (inversed subnet mask)

To allow us to isolate and figure out the host ID of an IP address by AND'ing then together

000.000.000.255
00000000.000000000.00000000.11111111
Modern Networks use what type of switching to communicate
Packet Switching
What 2 addresses must a packet include
A Destination address and a Source address
What is the TCP/IP stack

Application layer (HTTP/SMTP/DNS)
Transport layer (TCP/UDP)
Internet Layer (IP)
Network Access Layer (Ethernet/WiFi)
How do the layers in a TCP/IP stack communicate

Each layer provides services to the layer above and uses the services of the layer below

That is the physical path taken, however logically each layer communicates with the peer layer at the target system
Define Encapsulation
Each layer in the TCP/IP stack adds a header to the message
Define de-encapsulation
Each layer of the TCP/IP stack interprets the headers and replaces/removes them if necessary before passing it onto the next layer
Encapsulation example
What does PDU stand for
Protocol Data Units
What is the name of each PDU in a TCP/IP stack

Application layer (Message)
Transport layer (Segment)
Internet layer (Packet)
Network Access Layer (Frame)

Medium (Bits)
How many bits does a MAC address have
48 bits (6 bytes)
What two sections does a MAC address contain

The OUI (Organisation Unique Identifier) - 24 bits
A unique sequence number from the OUI owner - 24 bits
How are MAC addresses expressed

As six hexadecimal numbers seperated by colons

e.g. 00:0A:12:43:99:DB
What three possibilities could happen when a NIC receives a frame and compares the destination MAC with its own

1. If the MAC does not match, the frame is discarded
2. If the MAC matches, the payload is passed up to the internetwork layer for processing
3. If the MAC is a broadcast address, the payload is passed up to the internetwork layer for processing
What is a the source MAC address for an all-stations broadcast
FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF
WiFi and non-switched Ethernet receive which transmissions
All transmissions
Switched Ethernet receives which transmissions
Its own and broadcast transmissions
What does MAC stand for
Medium Access Control
What does NIC stand for
Network Interface Controller
What does FCS stand for
Frame Check Sequence
What does CSMA/CD stand for
Carrier Sense, Multiple Access / Collision Detection
What does ARP stand for
Address Resolution Protocol
What does DHCP stand for
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol
What does MTU stand for
Maximum Transmission Unit
What does ICMP stand for
Internet Control Message Protocol
What does VLSM stand for
Variable Length Subnet Masks
What VSLM and subnet mask would be for 10.0.0.1
What VSLM and subnet mask would be for 172.16.0.1
What VSLM and subnet mask would be for 192.168.0.1
What is the subnet mask if a /25 in dotted decimal and binary
Do broadcast messages pass through Routers/3 Layer Switches
No
Which is faster? Switching frames or Routing packets
Switching frames
What does DLNA stand for
Digital Living Network Alliance
What does EGP stand for
Exterior Gateway Protocols
What does IGP stand for
Interior Gateway Protocols
What 2 categories do IGPs fall into

Distance Vector Protocols
Link State Protocols
Which protocol segments messages, TCP or UDP
TCP
What is Application Multiplexing
Ports (essentially)
What is the range for well-known ports
What is the range for ephemeral ports
What is the purpose of an address and port
Allows for a unique IP address representing an application
What is the most common TCP/IP API called and what does it contain needed to communicate

Socket

Source and destination IP address,
Source and destination port
Sockets use a _____ _______ to access network services as the connection is treated as a _____ _______

file handle
byte stream
What does a socket address consist of

A protocol, IP address, port.

e.g. tcp,192.168.0.50,80
What is a socket connection represented as

An association which has the IP address and port of both the client and server.

e.g. tcp,192.168.0.50,80,172.16.100.22,50111
Which 2 main protocols does the Transport Layer provide

TCP
UDP
What is UDPs in a nutshell

UDP is connectionless (does not provide reliability, flow control or error recovery)
UDP has less overhead for transmission than TCP and is used in some streaming applications for this reason
UDP is also used for services like DNS, TFTP, RPC & LDAP which require small amounts of data
How many packets does a UDP transmission send
A single packet
What is the maximum payload size of a UDP Datagram
516 bytes
What is TCP in a nutshell

TCP is a connection-orientated protocol which provides a full-duplex byte stream between processes
TCP segments the byte stream to be passed to the Internetwork layer (done with knowledge of the Internetwork layer MTU)
TCP provides reliability using sequence numbers and acknowledgements (ACK)
TCP provides flow control via the receiver ACK mechanism (sliding window)
What type of handshake does a TCP connection use
Three Way Handshake
In a TCP three way handshake, what is the first requirement
A server must have a socket listening for incoming connections called a Passive Open
What does a TCP client send to a servers Passive Open socket
An Active Open call
What steps does an Active Open call consist of

The client sends a SYN (synchronise) message with a random SEQ (sequence) number (e.g. 2044)

If the server is not accepting requests it can reply with a NAK (negative acknowledgement)
If the server is accepting requests it replies with a SYN ACK (synchronise acknowledgement) with its own random SEQ number (e.g. 42000) and the next expected SEQ (2045)

The client completes the connection with an ACK containing the next SEQ (2045) and ACK containing the next SEQ from the server (42001)
What type of segment is sent to close a TCP connection
FIN segment
What does NAT stand for and what are the 2 common (but outdated) methods of NAT

Network Address Translation

SNAT
DNAT
What does SNAT stand for and how did it work

Static Network Address Translation

Translated internal private IPs to manually assigned public IPs for outgoing transmissions, and vica versa for incoming transmissions
What does PAT stand for
Port Address Translation
What is the purpose of NAT in a nutshell

NAT re-writes the source IP address (and port in PAT) of outgoing transmissions to an external IP and saves the combination of it and the internal IP (and port in PAT) to a NAT table, and vica versa for incoming transmissions using the NAT to translate back to the original address (and port in PAT)
What is the difference between NAT and PAT

PAT does the exact same thing as NAT, except it also re-writes the port on the external address allowing for 2^16 (65354) unique connections on a single external IP (usually 1 external IP available only)
In short, what is a VLAN
Virtual LAN, provides virtual broadcast domains
In short, what is DHCP
Automated TCP/IP configuration in hosts
What is another name for a VLAN tag
802.1q tag
How many bits are used in a 802.1q tag to identify the VLAN
12 bit field
How many values can fit in a 802.1q tag VLAN identifier field
What are the two types of configurations for VLAN access

Access Link
Trunk Link
What is the purpose of an Access Link

Used when a device only supports the standard Ethernet frame (most NICs)
Only supports a single VLAN assignment
What is the purpose of a Trunk Link

Usually connect two switches or a switch to a VLAN capable router
Carry a Logical connection for each VLAN carried over a single Physical connection
Support multiple VLANs
802.1q tags allow a receiving switch to select the destination port on both the VLAN ID and MAC address (in its CAM table)
Example of VLAN network
What are the advantages of VLANs

- Reduce size of broadcast domains
- Per port configuration permits higher security, users of each VLAN can't see broadcast traffic from other VLANs
- Location independence, devices don't have to be connected to the same switch to be a member of a subnet
- Users can be grouped by job category or security clearance rather than physical location
- Some switches can assign a higher priority to a specific VLAN
What is a "Router on a Stick"
A router that can understand 802.1q tagging with a trunk access connection between itself and a core switch, with multiple VLANs
What is a better alternative to the "Router on a Stick" method
A Layer 3 Switch used as the core switch
What does SVI stand for
Switched Virtual Interface
Why is a router still needed

- Switches only operate within a LAN
- Used for protocol conversion, access control, NAT and WAN links
What 3 parameters must be set on a host device in order to have TCP/IP connections

IP Address
Subnet Mask
Default Gateway
What is the process of a device acquiring an IP address with DHCP when it is turned on/connected

Device runs a DHCP client and requests an IP address and other config data
Each IP subnet requires access to a DHCP server that will assign and track allocated IP addresses
What happens if a DHCP server is unavailable
A device will self-assign an IP address using APIPA
What are the 3 methods of DHCP IP address allocation

Dynamic - allocates an IP lease, if lease expires without being renewed it is returned to the pool

Automatic - allocates an IP address from the pool but will remember which client requested the IP and try reallocate it when possible

Manual (Reservations) - allocates an IP address based on the clients MAC address from settings created by the server administrator
What protocol (TCP/UDP) does a DHCP protocol use for its client and server and on which ports

UDP

Client = 68
Server = 67
What is the DORA connection method

Discover - DHCP client sends out a broadcast message asking for an IP address or requesting one it had before

Offer - DHCP server responds using the clients MAC address with an IP address, subnet mask, lease duration and IP address of itself

Request - DHCP client responds to a single server and includes the servers IP address, broadcasts a reply to other servers denying their offer if needed

Acknowledge - DHCP server replies with a DHCPACK message, as well as lease duration and other configuration data requested
During the acknowledgement phase of a DCHP communication what are some things, in addition to the IP address, that the server can provide

DHCP server identifier
IP address lease time
Subnet mask
Router address (Default Gateway)
DNS server address
A default domain name
A client identifier (MAC address)
What does APIPA stand for
Automatic Private IP Addressing
What IP address range is used for APIPA
What does DNAT stand for and how did it work

Dynamic Network Address Translation

Translated internal private IPs to an available external public IP from a pool of available IPs for outgoing transmissions, and vica versa for incoming transmissions
What is star topology

Has a single link from each computer/node to a central computer or node.
It requires more cable then bus network but results in a more reliable network as any one link failure will not effect the other nodes, however it is vulnerable if the central node becomes unavailable
What is a ring topology

Does not contain a central node, instead, each node sends a message to a neighbour who, if necessary, will forward it onto a non-adjecent node that is the target node. It does not suffer from the loss of a central node as most ring networks can send a message the longer way around. There is an overhead however requiring each node to be able to forward messages and is slower than relaying through a central node.
What is a mesh topology

Every node is connected to every other node. Nodes can still communicate easily with a single link failure as they only require a single intermediate node. They are only used when there is a high redundancy requirement for mission critical operations and are often not full mesh networks
What is the formula to determine how many connections are required in a full mesh topology
What is a point to point topology
A single link between 2 nodes or networks
What is a hybrid topology

A hybrid of various other topologies

e.g. two star networks connected with a point to point connection between the central nodes creating a star if star network (a hierarchical star)
What is the difference between logical topology and and physical topology
Logical topology is a description of how a signal propegates on a network medium as opposed to the physical layout if the network.
What is the physical description of the now common switched topology
Most switched networks are hierarchical star networks, with groups of stars connected using either routers or layer 3 switches
What is the purpose of a NIC when transmitting over a medium
The NIC will convert a frame into a bit stream suitable for transmission on a specific medium
What criteria will selecting a physical medium depend on
The intended use of the network
What properties of a physical medium can be considered when selecting a medium for an intended purpose

Transmission speed or bandwidth
Effective distance
Susceptibility to interference
Security
Installation restrictions
Cost
What is the transmissions speed or bandwidth measured in on physical mediums

bps (bits per second)

NOT Bps (bytes per second)

e.g. Kbps, Mbps, Gbps
What is the purpose of a preample when transmitting
To signal to the receiver that a frame is about to begin
What are the properties of copper as a physical medium
Common conductor of electricity, used in 10base5 (thick coaxial), various versions of copper cabling have been used overtime, notably Ethernet.
What does UTP stand for
Unshielded Twister Pair
What is the range of transmission speeds for UTP cables

10Mbps - 40Gbps

(Standards for higher speeds but uncommon)
What what is the maximum distance for UTP, thin and thick coaxial

UTP = 100m
Thin = 185m
Thick = 500m
Generally, the faster the speed of transmission, the ______ the length of transmission possible
Shorter
Is UTP cabling susceptible to interference
Yes, it is susceptible to EMI (electromagnetic interference)
Is UTP susceptible to wire tapping
Yes, it is relatively easy to tap into copper cable either directly or by using an aerial next to the cable and to sense the variations in the electromagnetic field
What restrictions are there to consider for UTP cables
Very few but most notably is anything to do with interference (any strong source of electrical power)
Is UTP cheap
Compared to fibre optic, it is far cheaper and thus still common
How many fiber optic cables are required for a single wired connection
2, upstream and downstream
What is the range of transmission speed for optical cables
100Mbps - 100s of Gbps
What is the maximum distance a optical cable can support (as of now)
What characteristics does optical cable have to electromagnetic interference
It is immune to EMI
Is optical cable susceptible to wire tapping
Yes, but it is very difficult and requires specialised equipment
What are the installation restrictions of optical cable
It is delicate and can't be bent around tight corners or be handle frequently or roughly
Is optical cable cheap
Compared to UTP it is relatively expensive because of delicate install process and specialised skills involved
What is Structure Cabling
The process of linking devices to the nearest wiring closet
What is a wiring closet

A room, usually one per floor, that houses the local infrastructure (switches etc.). It will contain one or more racks that mount the patch panels and devices. They are usually connected to other wiring closets using optical cable
Where do all wiring closets on a site usually lead to
One building with a major wiring hub connecting all the buildings and will be the interconnect point for external data/internet connection etc.
